title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #790** asks: define l(n) as the maximum guaranteed sum-free subset size in any n-element set. Estimate l(n).

**Known Bounds (CKS 1975):**
- Lower: √(n log n / log log n)
- Upper: n / log n

**Status: OPEN** - The gap is huge.
mathContext: Sum-free here means no a = a₂ + ... + aᵣ with distinct elements, which is weaker than classical sum-free (no a + b = c).

title: IsSumFree
content:
A set B is sum-free if no element equals a sum of ≥2 distinct other elements.

Formally: ∀ a ∈ B, ∀ S ⊆ B\{a} with |S| ≥ 2, a ≠ Σ S.

This is weaker than classical sum-free (no a + b = c).

title: l(n) - The Extremal Function
content:
l(n) = min over all A with |A| = n of the maximum sum-free subset size.

Equivalently: l(n) is the largest k such that every n-set has a sum-free subset of size ≥ k.

title: Characterization of l(n)
content:
Two axioms characterize l(n):

**l_characterization:** Every n-set has a sum-free subset of size ≥ l(n).

**l_optimal:** For any k > l(n), some n-set has no sum-free subset of size ≥ k.

title: Erdős's Lower Bound
content:
**Erdős observed:** l(n) ≥ √(n/2)

Idea: In {1,...,n}, the upper half {⌊n/2⌋+1,...,n} is "almost" sum-free since sums of large numbers exceed n. One can extract √(n/2) elements that are strictly sum-free.

title: Choi's Improvement
content:
**Choi improved to:** l(n) > (1+c)√n for some constant c > 0.

This beats Erdős's √(n/2) ≈ 0.707√n by a constant factor.

title: CKS Lower Bound
content:
**Choi-Komlós-Szemerédi (1975):**

l(n) ≥ c √(n log n / log log n)

This is significantly better than √n for large n.

title: CKS Upper Bound
content:
**Choi-Komlós-Szemerédi (1975):**

l(n) ≤ C n / log n

This shows l(n) = o(n), answering Erdős's question.

title: Combined CKS Bounds
content:
**The CKS Sandwich:**

√(n log n / log log n) ≪ l(n) ≪ n / log n

The gap is from roughly n^{0.5+ε} to n^{1-ε}. The conjecture is that the upper bound is closer to the truth.

title: Question 1: l(n)/√n → ∞
content:
**Does l(n)/√n → ∞? YES!**

The CKS lower bound √(n log n / log log n) divided by √n gives √(log n / log log n) → ∞.

So l(n) grows faster than √n.

title: Question 2: l(n) < n^{1-c}
content:
**Is l(n) < n^{1-c} for some c > 0? YES!**

The CKS upper bound l(n) ≤ n/log n is o(n^{1-c}) for any c < 1.

Erdős claimed in 1965 he could prove l(n) = o(n) but couldn't reconstruct his proof by 1973.

title: CKS Conjecture
Classical vs Weak Sum-Free
content:
**Classical sum-free:** No a + b = c (3-term constraint)

**This problem (weak):** No a = a₂ + ... + aᵣ for r ≥ 2 (variable-term constraint)

The weak condition is easier to satisfy, so more sets are "sum-free." Classical implies weak.

title: Erdős's Lost Proof
content:
**The curious case of the lost proof:**

1965: Erdős wrote "by complicated arguments we can show l(n) = o(n)"

1973: "difficulties in reconstructing [his] proof"

The CKS 1975 paper provided the rigorous proof.

title: Summary
content:
**Erdős Problem #790: OPEN**

- Q1 (l(n)/√n → ∞?): YES
- Q2 (l(n) < n^{1-c}?): YES
- Main conjecture (l(n) ≥ n^{1-o(1)}?): OPEN

Known: √(n log n / log log n) ≤ l(n) ≤ n / log n
